cmCourseInfo.description: A brief introductory survey of psychology as both a biological and social science. Topics will include behavioural neuroscience, learning, perceptual, motivational, cognitive, developmental, personality, abnormal, and social psychology.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introductory Psychology

cmCourseInfo.description: A brief introductory survey of psychology as both a biological and social science. Topics will include behavioural neuroscience, learning, perceptual, motivational, cognitive, developmental, personality, abnormal, and social psychology.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introductory Psychology

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Throughout the term, students will be expected to watch asynchronous lecture videos. There will be two online term tests (each scheduled on a specific day and available for 24 hours) as well as an in-person, on-campus final exam (scheduled on a specific day by the Faculty of Arts and Sciences during the final exam period).  Support will be offered in the form of study guides, virtual office hours and online tutorials.

cmCourseInfo.description: Fundamentals of descriptive and inferential statistics, including population and sampling distributions, simple association, probability, estimation, and hypothesis testing.
cmCourseInfo.title: Statistics I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY100H1/ PSY100Y5/ (PSYA01H3 and PSYA02H3)/ COG250Y1
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: ECO220Y1/ EEB225H1/ GGR270H1/ IRW220H1/ POL222H1/ SOC202H1/ STA220H1/ STA238H1/ STA248H1/ STA288H1/ ECO220Y5/ PSY201H5/ STA215H5/ STA220H5/ PSYB07H3/ STAB22H3/ STAB23H3/ STAB57H3

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Course content will be delivered as online lecture recordings for students to view asynchronously.  Opportunities for synchronous activity with instructors and classmates (e.g., virtual office hours, weekly review sessions) will be made available and will be recorded and posted for asynchronous access when possible. Online synchronous activity is strongly recommended but not required.  All course assessments will be conducted online.

cmCourseInfo.description: Fundamentals of descriptive and inferential statistics, including population and sampling distributions, simple association, probability, estimation, and hypothesis testing.
cmCourseInfo.title: Statistics I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY100H1/ PSY100Y5/ (PSYA01H3 and PSYA02H3)/ COG250Y1

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Course content will be accessible online for students to view asynchronously.  All course assessments will be conducted online, with the exception of the final exam which will be in-person.  All students will be expected to be on campus for the final exam.

cmCourseInfo.description: Fundamentals of statistical analysis of experimental and observational data including linear models, the analysis of variance, a priori contrasts, post-hoc tests, power analysis and effect size calculations.
cmCourseInfo.title: Statistics II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY201H1/ EEB225H1/ GGR270H1/ IRW220H1/ POL222H1/ SOC202H1/ STA220H1/ STA238H1/ STA248H1/ STA288H1/ PSY201H5/ STA215H5/ STA220H5/ PSYB07H3/ STAB22H3/ STAB23H3
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: ECO220Y1/ SOC252H1/ STA221H1/ PSY202H5/ ECO220Y5/ STA221H5/ PSYC08H3/ STAB27H3/ STAC32H3

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

cmCourseInfo.description: This course provides an introduction to conceiving, designing, and conducting research in psychology. It prepares students to be both consumers and producers of scientific research, and also addresses basic issues related to the work of psychological scientists such as theory development, research ethics, and scientific writing. Students in this course will gain insight into the scientific process as a whole – its advantages, difficulties, and limitations. As such, students will be able to better evaluate the knowledge that psychological science can provide, and integrate that knowledge into a broader worldview.
cmCourseInfo.title: Psychological Research
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY100H1/ PSY100Y5/ (PSYA01H3 and PSYA02H3)/ COG250Y1
cmCourseInfo.corequisitesText: PSY201H1/ ECO220Y1/ EEB225H1/ GGR270H1/ IRW220H1/ POL222H1/ SOC202H1/ STA220H1/ STA238H1/ STA248H1/ STA288H1/ ECO220Y5/ PSY201H5/ STA215H5/ STA220H5/ PSYB07H3/ STAB22H3/ STAB23H3

cmCourseInfo.description: The developmental approach to the study of behaviour with a focus on infancy through childhood. Topics include sensorimotor skills, cognition, socialization, personality, and emotional behaviour.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Developmental Psychology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY100H1/ PSY100Y5/ PSYA02H3/ COG250Y1

cmCourseInfo.description: Contemporary areas of research in social psychology: social perception, attitudes, inter-personal relations, and group processes.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Social Psychology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY100H1/PSY100Y5/PSYA02H3/COG250Y1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

ONLINE VIA QUERCUS: Lectures will be delivered as recorded content on Monday morning before each week's Companion Lecture on Wednesday. Students are expected to watch the Monday lecture before, then attend live Zoom Companion Lecture (Wednesdays 1 to 2:30pm). Companion Lectures will expand on and engage with topics from each week's content. The midterm test will be conducted on Quercus during the first 2 hours (1 to 3pm) of class time on the dates under Course Evaluation (TBD). Papers will be handed in through Quercus. The final exam will be held in-person during the final exam period.

cmCourseInfo.description: Theory and research in personality structure and dynamics: the interaction of cultural and biological factors in the development and expression of individual differences.
cmCourseInfo.title: Personality and Its Transformations
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY100H1/ PSY100Y5/ PSYA02H3/ COG250Y1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Course content will be accessible online for students to view asynchronously.  All course assessments will be conducted online, with the exception of the final exam which will be in-person.  All students will be expected to be on campus for the final exam.

cmCourseInfo.description: Concepts, theories, and applications of classical and contemporary learning theories, including classical and operant conditioning. Current theories of the physiological and anatomical basis of learning and memory, including synaptic plasticity, the role of the hippocampus, amygdala, frontal cortex and other brain regions. Theories will be related to a practical understanding and applications such as drug addiction, phobias and other disorders.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Learning and Plasticity
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY100H1/PSY100Y5/PSYA01H3/COG250Y1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to research and theory on the neural and cognitive architecture of attention, memory, language, thinking and reasoning.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Cognitive Psychology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY100H1/PSY100Y5/PSYA01H3/COG250Y1

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the physiological and psychological basis of perception across the different sensory modalities in humans and lower animals, with an emphasis on vision. Exploring visual perception such as shape and objects, scenes, colour, space, and motion as well as auditory perception of simple and complex sounds, and location. Further topics may include touch, including perception of temperature, pain and body posture, the chemical senses, and cross-modal influences of the senses on one another. In-class demonstrations may supplement the lectures.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Sensation and Perception
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY100H1/ PSY100Y5/ PSYA01H3/ COG250Y1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Students are expected to watch asynchronous lecture videos and perform and document practical demonstrations according to online instructions. Students will participate in an online discussion forum. Learning progress will be assessed in a midterm and final exam. All activities during the semester will be conducted online, as will the midterm and final exam.

cmCourseInfo.description: Provides students with a solid background in the biological basis of behaviour. Animal and human research topics will include functional neuroanatomy and neural signalling. Further topics may include sensory and motor control, motivational systems, hormones, and emotions, among other topics.
cmCourseInfo.title: Behavioural Neuroscience
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY100H1/ PSY100Y5/ PSYA01H3/ COG250Y1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

cmCourseInfo.description: Credit course for supervised participation in faculty research project. Details at https://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/academics/research-opportunities/research-opportunities-program. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Opportunity Program

cmCourseInfo.description: Special Topics in Psychology for the Summer Abroad Program. Course topics, content, and instructor may vary from one year to another. More information about Psychology and other course offerings can be obtained from the Summer Abroad website at https://summerabroad.utoronto.ca/. For students in any Psychology and/or Social Science Major or Specialist.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Psychology Abroad
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of 8.0 credits

cmCourseInfo.description: An intensive study of social attitude development, description, measurement, modification, and organization.
cmCourseInfo.title: Social Psychology: Attitudes
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY201H1/ ECO220Y1/ EEB225H1/ GGR270H1/ IRW220H1/ POL222H1/ SOC202H1/ STA220H1/ STA238H1/ STA248H1/ STA288H1/ ECO220Y5/ PSY201H5/ STA215H5/ STA220H5/ PSYB07H3/ STAB22H3/ STAB23H3/ STAB57H3, and PSY220H1/ PSY220H5/ PSYB10H3/ SOC213H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

ONLINE VIA QUERCUS: Lectures will be delivered as recorded content the week before the set online Companion Lectures. Students are expected to watch the lecture before, then attend live Zoom Companion Lecture (Mondays & Thursdays 9am-10am). The Midterm will be conducted on Quercus during the first 2 hours (9am-11am) of class time on the dates under Course Evaluation (Thursday May 22nd). Papers will be handed in through Quercus. The final will be online during the final exam period.

cmCourseInfo.description: One of the hallmarks of human behaviour is its diversity. Some of the ways in which we differ are thought to be relatively idiosyncratic (e.g., specific aspects of personality), whereas others are fairly systematic. Cultural psychology is one area of research in human behaviour that examines systematic differences resulting from individuals’ cultural backgrounds. This course will introduce you to the consideration of cultural variation in the study of human thought and behaviour.
cmCourseInfo.title: Cross-Cultural Psychology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY201H1/ ECO220Y1/ EEB225H1/ GGR270H1/ IRW220H1/ POL222H1/ SOC202H1/ STA220H1/ STA238H1/ STA248H1/ STA288H1/ ECO220Y5/ PSY201H5/ STA215H5/ STA220H5/ PSYB07H3/ STAB22H3/ STAB23H3/ STAB57H3, and PSY220H1/ PSY220H5/ PSYB10H3/ SOC213H1

cmCourseInfo.description: This course deals with psychological issues in the law, with particular reference to criminal law. It focuses mainly on research that has been done on pretrial publicity, eyewitness testimony, rules of evidence, and other factors that might affect jury decisions.
cmCourseInfo.title: Psychology and the Law
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY201H1/ ECO220Y1/ EEB225H1/ GGR270H1/ IRW220H1/ POL222H1/ SOC202H1/ STA220H1/ STA238H1/ STA248H1/ STA288H1/ ECO220Y5/ PSY201H5/ STA215H5/ STA220H5/ PSYB07H3/ STAB22H3/ STAB23H3/ STAB57H3, and PSY220H1/ PSY220H5/ PSYB10H3/ SOC213H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

ONLINE VIA QUERCUS: Lectures will be delivered as recorded content the week before the set online Companion Lectures. Students are expected to watch the lecture before, then attend live Zoom Companion Lecture (Mondays & Thursdays 11am-12pm). The midterm will be conducted on Quercus during the last 2 hours (11am-1pm) of class time on the dates under Course Evaluation (Monday May 26th). Papers will be handed in through Quercus. The final will be online during the final exam period.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines research evidence concerning the impact of psychological factors on physical health and illness.
cmCourseInfo.title: Health Psychology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY201H1/ ECO220Y1/ EEB225H1/ GGR270H1/ IRW220H1/ POL222H1/ SOC202H1/ STA220H1/ STA238H1/ STA248H1/ STA288H1/ ECO220Y5/ PSY201H5/ STA215H5/ STA220H5/ PSYB07H3/ STAB22H3/ STAB23H3/ STAB57H3, and one of PSY230H1/ PSY230H5/ PSYB30H3, or PSY240H1/ PSY240H5/ PSYB32H3

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online course with an in-person final exam. Lectures will be pre-recorded and delivered online asynchronously. There will be opportunities for live discussion with the instructor and/or TA during scheduled Zoom meetings. Students need the ability to read and edit PDFs or Powerpoint slides and use Quercus for submission of the assignments and online midterm test. The final exam will be in-person during the final exam period. There will not be a remote option for completing the final exam: Students must be able to attend the in-person final exam at the University during the final exam period to complete this course.

cmCourseInfo.description: A review of the field of positive psychology, which is the study of happiness and fulfillment. Topics include personal growth, meaning, hedonic and eudaimonic approaches to well-being, gratitude, awe, flow states, mindfulness and meditation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Positive Psychology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY201H1/ ECO220Y1/ EEB225H1/ GGR270H1/ IRW220H1/ POL222H1/ SOC202H1/ STA220H1/ STA238H1/ STA248H1/ STA288H1/ ECO220Y5/ PSY201H5/ STA215H5/ STA220H5/ PSYB07H3/ STAB22H3/ STAB23H3/ STAB57H3, and one of PSY220H1/ PSY220H5/ PSYB10H3/ SOC213H1, or PSY230H1/ PSY230H5/ PSYB30H3, or PSY240H1/ PSY240H5/ PSYB32H3

cmCourseInfo.description: A review of the field of positive psychology, which is the study of happiness and fulfillment. Topics include personal growth, meaning, hedonic and eudaimonic approaches to well-being, gratitude, awe, flow states, mindfulness and meditation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Positive Psychology

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines various theories of how personality functioning may become impaired and corresponding psychotherapeutic interventions. Emphasis on empirical assessment of personality dysfunction and therapy effectiveness.
cmCourseInfo.title: Theories of Psychopathology and Psychotherapy
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY201H1/ ECO220Y1/ EEB225H1/ GGR270H1/ IRW220H1/ POL222H1/ SOC202H1/ STA220H1/ STA238H1/ STA248H1/ STA288H1/ ECO220Y5/ PSY201H5/ STA215H5/ STA220H5/ PSYB07H3/ STAB22H3/ STAB23H3/ STAB57H3, and one of PSY230H1/ PSY230H5/ PSYB30H3, or PSY240H1/ PSY240H5/ PSYB32H3

cmCourseInfo.description: Current theories and data on human memory: processes involved in encoding, storage, and retrieval.
cmCourseInfo.title: Human Memory
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY201H1/ ECO220Y1/ EEB225H1/ GGR270H1/ IRW220H1/ POL222H1/ SOC202H1/ STA220H1/ STA238H1/ STA248H1/ STA288H1/ ECO220Y5/ PSY201H5/ STA215H5/ STA220H5/ PSYB07H3/ STAB22H3/ STAB23H3/ STAB57H3, and one of PSY260H1/ PSYB38H3 or PSY270H1/ PSY270H5/ PSYB57H3/ COG250Y1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be pre-recorded, and delivered online asynchronously. All course assessments will be conducted online.  No final exam.

cmCourseInfo.description: The functional relevance of neurotransmitters, with particular emphasis on their role in mediating behaviour.
cmCourseInfo.title: Neurochemical Basis of Behaviour
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY201H1/ ECO220Y1/ EEB225H1/ GGR270H1/ IRW220H1/ POL222H1/ SOC202H1/ STA220H1/ STA238H1/ STA248H1/ STA288H1/ ECO220Y5/ PSY201H5/ STA215H5/ STA220H5/ PSYB07H3/ STAB22H3/ STAB23H3/ STAB57H3, and one of PSY260H1/ PSYB38H3 or PSY290H1/ PSY290H5/ PSYB64H3/ HMB200H1/ PSL300H1

cmCourseInfo.description: Credit course for supervised participation in faculty research project. Details at https://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/academics/research-opportunities/research-opportunities-program. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Opportunity Program

cmCourseInfo.description: A single semester intensive laboratory or applied research project for students who seek hands-on research experience to complement our regular course offerings. Each project culminates in a scholarly paper and oral presentation. Students must secure a faculty supervisor from the Dept. of Psychology and submit a completed application form that includes details about the project before the start of the semester. Application forms are available on the Department’s website (https://psych.utoronto.ca/programs-and-courses/undergraduate-course-information) and must be emailed to the undergraduate office (psy.undergrad@utoronto.ca) by the end of the second week of September for fall projects, or by the end of the second week in January for winter projects. If you’re registering for a summer project, please submit it by the end of the second week in May. This course is open to all students.
cmCourseInfo.title: Individual Projects
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY202H1/ ECO220Y1/ SOC252H1/ STA221H1/ ECO220Y5/ PSY202H5/ STA221H5/ PSYC08H3/ STAB27H3/ STAC32H3, and the appropriate background in Psychology for the proposed work (e.g., PSY210H1 if the project is in the area of Developmental Psychology)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

For PSY405H1 and 406H1, 'E' indicator: Students must first obtain consent of a faculty member in the Department to supervise their project.  Information and application form are available on our website at https://psych.utoronto.ca/current-program-students/undergraduate-courses.  The electronic application form, signed by both student and supervisor, should be submitted to the Undergraduate Administrator for approval via email (psy.undergrad@utoronto.ca).

cmCourseInfo.description: A full academic year intensive laboratory or applied research project for students who seek hands-on research experience to complement our regular course offerings. Each project culminates in a scholarly paper and oral presentation. Students must secure a faculty supervisor from the Dept. of Psychology and submit a completed application form that includes details about the project before the start of the academic year. Application forms are available on the Department’s website (https://psych.utoronto.ca/programs-and-courses/undergraduate-course-information) and must be emailed to the undergraduate office (psy.undergrad@utoronto.ca) by the end of the second week of September. This course is open to all students.

cmCourseInfo.description: This lecture course focuses on the social psychology of interpersonal relationships between individuals, especially romantic or close relationships and friendships. It surveys what social psychologists have learned about the development, maintenance, disruption or dissolution of personal relationships, as well as current social psychological theories of interpersonal relationships.
cmCourseInfo.title: Social Psychology of Interpersonal Relationships
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY201H1/ ECO220Y1/ EEB225H1/ GGR270H1/ IRW220H1/ POL222H1/ SOC202H1/ STA220H1/ STA238H1/ STA248H1/ STA288H1/ ECO220Y5/ PSY201H5/ STA215H5/ STA220H5/ PSYB07H3/ STAB22H3/ STAB23H3/ STAB57H3, and PSY220H1/ PSY220H5/ PSYB10H3/ SOC213H1

cmCourseInfo.description: This is a capstone lecture course surveying research on how the mind arises from the brain. The first objective of the course is to understand how processes in human brains (ranging from the firing of a single neuron to the dynamics of billions) support cognitive abilities (such as recognizing a face, remembering a birthday from childhood, understanding the words in a spoken lecture, or planning a route home from class). The second objective of the course is to understand the methods of contemporary cognitive neuroscience research, to enable students to read primary literature and to understand ongoing debates.
cmCourseInfo.title: Cognitive Neuroscience
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY201H1/ ECO220Y1/ EEB225H1/ GGR270H1/ IRW220H1/ POL222H1/ SOC202H1/ STA220H1/ STA238H1/ STA248H1/ STA288H1/ ECO220Y5/ PSY201H5/ STA215H5/ STA220H5/ PSYB07H3/ STAB22H3/ STAB23H3/ STAB57H3, and one of PSY260H1/ PSYB38H3 or PSY270H1/ PSY270H5/ PSYB57H3/ COG250Y1 or PSY290H1/ PSY290H5/ PSYB64H3/ HMB200H1/ PSL300H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment
